title: 1988–89 Winnipeg Jets season
text:
The 1988–89 <a href="Winnipeg%20Jets%20%281972%E2%80%9396%29">Winnipeg Jets</a> season saw the Jets finish in fifth place in the <a href="Smythe%20Division">Smythe Division</a> with a record of 26 wins, 42 losses, and 12 ties for 64 points, missing the playoffs for the first time since 1981.
Off-season.
After two seasons of leading the Jets into the playoffs, the club re-signed head coach <a href="Don%20Maloney">Don Maloney</a> to a contract extension through the <a href="1990%E2%80%9391%20NHL%20season">1990–91 season</a> on May 16, 1988. At the <a href="1988%20NHL%20Entry%20Draft">1988 NHL Entry Draft</a> held on June 11, 1988, the Jets selected forward <a href="Teemu%20Sel%C3%A4nne">Teemu Selanne</a> with their first round draft pick, tenth overall. Selanne spent the 1987–88 playing with <a href="Jokerit">Jokerit</a>'s junior hockey team, where in 33 games, he recorded 43 goals and 66 points.
On June 13, 1988, the Jets acquired <a href="Brent%20Ashton">Brent Ashton</a> from the <a href="Detroit%20Red%20Wings">Detroit Red Wings</a> in exchange for <a href="Paul%20MacLean%20%28ice%20hockey%29">Paul MacLean</a>. Ashton had 26 goals and 53 points in 73 games with the Red Wings in <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20NHL%20season">1987–88</a>. MacLean, who had been with Winnipeg since the <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20Winnipeg%20Jets%20season">1981–82 season</a>, had 40 goals and 79 points in 77 games. In total, MacLean broke the 40-goal plateau three times as a member with the Jets.
On July 19, 1988, Winnipeg made a trade with the <a href="New%20Jersey%20Devils">New Jersey Devils</a>, acquiring goaltender <a href="Alain%20Chevrier">Alain Chevrier</a> and the Devils' seventh-round pick in the <a href="1989%20NHL%20Entry%20Draft">1989 NHL Entry Draft</a> for <a href="Steve%20Rooney">Steve Rooney</a> and the Jets' third-round pick in the <a href="1990%20NHL%20Entry%20Draft">1990 NHL Entry Draft</a>. Chevrier had a record of 18–19–3 with a 3.77 <a href="goals%20against%20average">goals against average</a> (GAA) in 45 games with the Devils in <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20NHL%20season">1987–88</a>, while <a href="Steve%20Rooney">Steve Rooney</a> had 7 goals and 13 points, along with 217 penalty minutes, in 56 games with the Jets in <a href="1987%E2%80%9388%20Winnipeg%20Jets%20season">1987–88</a>.
Late in training camp, on September 29, 1988, the Jets acquired <a href="Kent%20Carlson">Kent Carlson</a> and the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Blues">St. Louis Blues</a>' tenth-round pick in the 1989 NHL Entry Draft and fourth-round pick in the 1990 NHL Entry Draft for <a href="Peter%20Douris">Peter Douris</a>. Carlson would then be traded one week into the 1988–89 season to the <a href="Washington%20Capitals">Washington Capitals</a>. On October 3, 1988, the Jets picked <a href="Dave%20Hunter">Dave Hunter</a> from the <a href="Edmonton%20Oilers">Edmonton Oilers</a> in the NHL Waiver Draft. Hunter split the 1987–88 season between the Oilers and <a href="Pittsburgh%20Penguins">Pittsburgh Penguins</a>, scoring 14 goals and 35 points in 80 games.
Regular season.
Despite finishing last in goals allowed (355) in the NHL, the Jets had the NHL's fifth-best power-play percentage (22.13%).
Playoffs.
The Jets missed the playoffs, the first time since the 1980–81 season.
Draft picks.
The Jets selected the following players at the <a href="1988%20NHL%20Entry%20Draft">1988 NHL Entry Draft</a>, which was held at the <a href="Montreal%20Forum">Montreal Forum</a> in <a href="Montreal">Montreal, Quebec</a>, on June 11, 1988.
NHL Supplemental Draft.
Winnipeg selected one player at the <a href="1988%20NHL%20Supplemental%20Draft">1988 NHL Supplemental Draft</a>.
